content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Secret Service Accountability and Improvement Act of 2014". Several recent failures have highlighted lapses in the protective mission of the United States Secret Service, including unauthorized access to the White House and incidents of personnel misconduct. Several recent failures have highlighted lapses in the protective mission of the United States Secret Service, including unauthorized access to the White House and incidents of personnel misconduct. A semiautomatic rifle struck the White House building with seven bullets, but the incident was not fully investigated or disclosed promptly. Instances of misconduct include a Special Agent found unconscious in a hotel in Amsterdam and serious misconduct by nine personnel before a Presidential visit to Cartagena, Columbia. Surveillance personnel were diverted from their protective mission in 2011 at the request of senior leadership. The request to provide protection to a Secret Service employee at her home was outside the agency's duties and violated ethical standards. Protecting the President and other high-profile individuals is crucial for national security, and any distractions from this mission pose a threat to the country. An independent advisory panel is established in the legislative branch to examine and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department of Homeland Security's mission to protect national leaders and special events. The panel will also make recommendations to enhance the United States Secret Service. The independent advisory panel, referred to as the "Panel," will consist of eight members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the majority leader of the Senate, in coordination with relevant committees. Only one member from each party can be appointed by the Speaker and the majority leader. The Panel consists of eight members appointed by various leaders, including the Speaker of the House and the majority leader of the Senate. Members appointed by the President must consult with the Secretary of Homeland Security, and only one member can be from the same political party as the President. Members of the Panel cannot be current appointees of the President. The Panel, consisting of eight members appointed by different leaders, must not include current appointees of the President or Members of Congress to ensure objectivity. No member can have been a Secret Service employee. Appointments must be made within 90 days. The Panel will have two co-chairs designated by the Speaker of the House and the majority leader of the Senate. Vacancies will be filled by the same appointing officer. The Panel, consisting of eight members appointed by different leaders, must not include current appointees of the President or Members of Congress to ensure objectivity. Appointments must be made within 90 days. The Panel will have two co-chairs designated by the Speaker of the House and the majority leader of the Senate. Vacancies will be filled by the same appointing officer. Members who are government employees serve without additional pay. The Panel must begin operations within 60 days of all members being appointed. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Panel will evaluate the leadership structure, training, and capabilities of the United States Secret Service, including unity of effort, personnel culture, security breaches, and impact on terrorism threats. The Panel will assess security breaches at Secret Service locations in the past five years, resource adequacy, communication effectiveness, and recommendations for Congress. SEC. 6. POWERS AND AUTHORITIES. The Panel has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and require witnesses to attend and provide evidence. Hearings conducted under this section must be open to the public unless determined otherwise by the Panel. The Panel has the authority to issue subpoenas for information related to national security or sensitive law enforcement data. Subpoenas can only be issued by the two co-chairs or with the affirmative vote of six members. Subpoenas can be signed by the co-chairs or designated members and served by designated individuals. The Panel can issue subpoenas for national security or law enforcement data. Subpoenas are issued by co-chairs or designated members and can be enforced by the court in case of non-compliance. The Panel can certify a statement of fact to the United States attorney for further action, with authorities provided in title 5, United States Code, and subject to specified conditions. The co-chairs of the Panel have the authority to appoint a staff director and necessary personnel without following standard government appointment and pay regulations. Employees from the Federal Government can also be detailed to the Panel without reimbursement. The Panel can procure expert and consultant services at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. They can also accept voluntary and uncompensated services. The appropriate government departments must cooperate with the Panel on security clearances. The Panel can enter into contracts and use postal services as needed. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request on a reimbursable basis. The Panel may establish rules for its business conduct, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to it. The Panel will terminate 60 days after submitting its final report. SEC. 7. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Panel appointed must submit an interim report to specified committees within nine months, including assessment results. They may also provide additional reports and briefings as needed. A final report must be submitted within eighteen months of the Panel's appointment. The Panel appointed must submit a final report to specified committees within eighteen months, including findings, lessons learned, and recommendations for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department of Homeland Security's mission. The Panel appointed must submit a final report to specified committees within eighteen months, including findings, lessons learned, and recommendations for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department of Homeland Security's mission. In accordance with section 3056(e) of title 18 United States Code, the report should focus on improving unity of effort, communication, cultural issues, and risk mitigation within the United States Secret Service.
